title: Agbe
author: Agbe
content: Bitcoin Class in the Church 14th August, 2o22. (Christian Youth in the Digital World)On the 14th August, 2022, I taught my church members about bitcoin through a topic from the Sunday School Manuel, Christian Youth in the Digital World. In the class I taught them the basic concepts of bitcoin and it definitions and other digital tools and devices which is used to navigate the digital world (internet). The class was divided into two adult and children. And I took the adult class and I started with the explanation of Christian Youth in the Digital World, that is how Christian should used the digital world to benefit themselves and also to enhance the gospel, instead of using to defraud people, watching pornography and evil things etc and the tools and devices (Mobile phones, Laptops, Desktops, IPhones etc, then Social Media). What you do in life and your appearance also influence others to go to church.  Then  I started teaching Bitcoin with some related concepts like decentralized, Trustless, p2p, digital, currency, Immutable, decentralized digital currency, space, ecosystem, Disintermediated, Distributed, blockchain, cryptocurrency, Hard Capped, Censorship resistant, nodes, Real estate, Secure personal information. These were some of the things I taught in the Sunday School Class on Sunday. And the women with the Pastor were very happy that I taught them such vital information that them have not aware of. If you want to read the Topic from the Sunday School Manuel, go to a nearby Church of God Mission INT.L. Page 30 - 35. you will understand everything there.

comments.author: jackg
comments.body: This seems like an interesting concept because of the demographic you'd see in a church. Do you know what ages you were teaching. (The majority of church goers here I'd say were under 20 or over 50-60 so it'd be quite an interesting group to educate on bitcoin - I've seen churches have a lot more variety of ages but those seem to be a lot bigger and have more of a chance for younger adults to acquire social contacts like older congregation members do).

comments.author: Fundamentals Of
comments.body: I applaud you for finding a way to spread information about Bitcoin. It is also good that your church and your pastor allowed you to use the Sunday opportunity for teaching about Bitcoin. It is a great opportunity considering that many of the members would usually flock to the church on that day for regular services. You'd get a bigger audience this way.While I don't like that Bitcoin will be appreciated with blind faith or that people would immediately support it just because their pastors or religious leaders say so, I agree that it could indeed be used to bring about good things, which must be what the gospels are all about.

comments.author: Piesel
comments.body: As much as I will commend you for this, I will also like to point out the fact that this topic is more appropriate in the off-topic section since there is nothing to discuss that is related to Bitcoin development.For the fact that this is just a religious time out something none conventional that does not have a continuous lifespan,  just a one Sunday thing can not add much to the body of bitcoin education.The only way this is will most effective is to have a fixed time for this teaching on several Sundays to cover more important topics like trading and mining, because those are the major practical aspects in bitcoin education if you want to build trust and confidence in the mind of your listeners.

comments.author: Cryptomultiplier
comments.body: It is good to have added knowledge to the beautiful minds who paid heed to your teachings on that day. More sessions should be created to further expatiate on the technicalities and terms you have introduced them to, so as not to render your candid effort futile. Bitcoin is the future of trade and investment. It is here to stay.

comments.author: Zlantann
comments.body: The digital world gives enormous opportunities that people mostly the youths can tap into and better their lives. And Bitcoin is one of those uncommon opportunity. But one of the greatest challenges of these youths is inaccessibility to the right information. Due to the level underdevelopment and poverty in most developing countries, they become cheap target or prey to fraudsters and get-rich-quick promoters. Hence, most of the information they receive about Bitcoin are diluted and sometimes untrue. Thank you OP for striving to give the appropriate information about Bitcoin to the church congregation.

comments.author: Asiska02
comments.body: You’re done a very great job in spreading the news of bitcoin to your worship center, I hope they find it worthy and  embrace in venturing into it. It is very hard to persuade the older generations on how the digital world is moving fast, they were not expose to many of this especially those that don’t have basic formal education during their tender and youthful age. Only few will find it worthy and venture into it, I just hope those that you’ve enlightened about it will take a bold step in accepting and venturing into it.

comments.author: hZti
comments.body: I see many times post about bitcoin classes in African countries and do really appreciate the effort that can help your community. What I would be interested in, is if you have any statistics of how many "students" actually start using bitcoin after your taught them about it.

comments.author: Rruchi man
comments.body: Quote from: Agbe on August 15, 2022, 11:03:16 PMOn the 14th August, 2022, I taught my church members about bitcoin through a topic from the Sunday School Manuel, Christian Youth in the Digital World. This is a good thing that people in church be made aware and given proper information about the digital space to nip in the bud any misconception that may arise due to being too religious or over spiritual. Some over spiritual and religious persons can sometimes become too rigid in thinking and not easily accept some new innovations. To a young brother in church who suddenly begins to do well financially because he invested in crypto, some other uninformed members of the church may have a misconception that he has involved himself with something fraudulent when they hear crypto (I site my example in consideration of my environment, it may not be the same with your environment). This sort of brief bitcoin class that you have somehow introduced into your Sunday school lectures can go a long way in clearing the misconception that anybody who involves in crypto is a fraudulent individual. Christians can still be involved in cryptocurrency, It is not a sin.
